classical: Liar Paradox: This sentence is false.
Russell's Paradox: The set of all sets that do not contain themselves.
Barber Paradox: The barber shaves all and only those who do not shave themselves.
Berry Paradox: 'The smallest positive integer not definable in under sixty letters.'
Grelling–Nelson Paradox: 'Autological' describes itself, 'heterological' does not.
Crocodile Paradox: A crocodile steals a child, promises return if parent guesses correctly.
Unexpected Hanging Paradox: A prisoner is told he will be hanged on an unexpected day.
Sorites Paradox: When does a heap of sand cease to be a heap when grains are removed?
Ship of Theseus: If all parts are replaced, is it still the same ship?
Epimenides Paradox: 'All Cretans are liars' said Epimenides, a Cretan.
temporal: Bootstrap Paradox: Information or object exists without being created.
Grandfather Paradox: Time traveler prevents own existence by killing grandfather.
Predestination Paradox: Event causes its own cause through time travel.
Polchinski's Paradox: Billiard ball enters wormhole to hit its past self.
Temporal Causality Loop: Event causes itself through closed timelike curves.
The Killing Hitler Paradox: Consequences of preventing major historical events.
The Ontological Paradox: Information exists with no point of origin.
The Consistency Paradox: Time travel must preserve self-consistency.
The Time Traveler's Dilemma: Meeting your future/past self.
The Causal Loop Paradox: Effect precedes cause indefinitely.
quantum: Schrödinger's Cat: Quantum superposition of alive/dead states.
EPR Paradox: Quantum entanglement appears to violate locality.
Quantum Zeno Effect: Frequent measurement prevents quantum evolution.
Wigner's Friend: Observer's measurement creates reality for another observer.
Hardy's Paradox: Quantum mechanics allows contradictory inferences.
The Quantum Cheshire Cat: Particle separated from its properties.
Delayed Choice Quantum Eraser: Present choices affect past events.
The Measurement Problem: When/how does wavefunction collapse occur?
Quantum Immortality: Many-worlds interpretation suggests subjective immortality.
The Quantum Suicide Thought Experiment: Probability of survival approaches 1.
mathematical: Banach-Tarski Paradox: Sphere decomposed into two identical spheres.
Gödel's Incompleteness Theorems: True but unprovable statements.
Skolem's Paradox: Countable models of uncountable sets.
Hausdorff Paradox: Sphere minus countable set can be partitioned into congruent pieces.
Gabriel's Horn: Infinite surface area but finite volume.
Zeno's Paradoxes: Motion is impossible (Achilles and tortoise, etc.).
Cantor's Paradox: Set of all sets leads to contradiction.
Burali-Forti Paradox: Set of all ordinal numbers is contradictory.
Richard's Paradox: Definability paradox about real numbers.
The Halting Problem: Cannot determine if arbitrary program halts.
information: The Library of Babel: Finite but effectively infinite library containing all books.
Maxwell's Demon: Thought experiment violating second law of thermodynamics.
Newcomb's Paradox: Choice between one box or two with predictive entity.
The Unexpected Examination: Student cannot be given an unexpected exam.
The Knowability Paradox: If all truths are knowable, then all truths are known.
The Raven Paradox: Observing non-black non-ravens confirms 'all ravens are black'.
The Lottery Paradox: Each ticket likely loses, but one must win.
The Preface Paradox: Author believes each statement but not all collectively.
The Paradox of Analysis: How can analysis be both correct and informative?
Moore's Paradox: 'It is raining but I don't believe it is raining.'
philosophical: The Problem of Evil: Evil exists in world created by omnipotent, omnibenevolent God.
Buridan's Ass: Donkey equidistant between food and water starves deciding.
The Ship of Theseus: Identity through complete replacement of parts.
The Trolley Problem: Ethical dilemma of sacrificing one to save many.
Theseus' Paradox: Identity through gradual replacement.
The Sorites Paradox: Vague predicates lead to contradiction.
The Heap Paradox: When does a collection become a heap?
The Paradox of Fiction: Emotional responses to fictional characters.
The Paradox of Hedonism: Pursuit of pleasure prevents achieving it.
The Prisoner's Dilemma: Rational choice leads to suboptimal outcome.
